newsitem.title: USA: US group -- willing to label beef to get EU sales.
newsitem.headline: US group -- willing to label beef to get EU sales.

text.p: National Cattlemen's Beef Association said Thursday it was willing to label U.S. beef in order to gain access to EU consumers on the heels of a World Trade Organization ruling against the EU "hormone beef" ban.

"We realize we are a long way from shipping product to the EU. But this is a major hurdle we needed to overcome," said Mark Armentrout, chairman of NCBA's international markets committee. "We are very excited by this initial ruling."
"We are willing to label our product as a product of the United States," Armentrout said in a telephone news conference.
The WTO ruling was an interim report which does not become final for a month. The EU could appeal or offer to pay compensation to the United States rather than open its market.
"Paying compensation is not an acceptable alternative to us," Armentrout said. "The European consumer is the one who should be making the decision...rather than her country's government.

Armentrout and NCBA economist Chuck Lambert said they believed there was a large potential market in Europe for U.S. beef. The EU ban cut off at least $100 million and as much as $250 million a year in sales, they said.
Sales of high-quality U.S. beef are limited to 11,200 tonnes this year under a tariff-rate quota.
While the U.S. beef industry was willing to label its product, Armentrout said, "we are not going to put something on it that connotes a negative image of the product."
Asked if the U.S. industry would accept a label that said the meat was produced with synthetic hormones, Armentrout replied, "Let's just say that's a negotiating point."
Lambert and Armentrout said the WTO ruling would provide assurance worldwide of the wholesomeness of U.S. beef.
